body.p: When thinking about the way the lymph system handles the interstitial fluid, it may be helpful to visualize an area after a very heavy rain. The ground becomes saturated so water and some minerals leach out of the ground and collect in puddles. This would be analogous to accumulating outside of the circulatory system and into the tissues. When this happens we often refer to the area with accumulated fluid as being . Eventually this excess fluid finds its way to the , which are pretty leaky and don’t really filter the fluid, much the same way a small stream will accumulate the run-off water after the rain. The fluid inside the lymph capillary is now called and is pale yellow in color. The lymph fluid is propelled through the capillary when drains into larger lymph much the same way a small stream empties into a larger creek. The larger creek usually empties into a river. In the case of this analogy the larger lymph run parallel to the blood vessel. The lymph in the large vessels drains into the larger near the heart in the chest. Like a river with a beaver dam, along the way the lymph vessels while drain into which remove some of the debris and foreign matter found circulating in the lymph slowing down the fluid flow and allowing the cells of the immune system to do their job.

response.feedback: Incorrect. When fluid leaves the capillary it is usually a bulk flow mechanism meaning that content of the fluid doesn’t appreciably change.
Correct. The space between cells is referred to as interstitial.
Incorrect. Water is the largest single component but not the only component.
Incorrect. This is a normal process and does not require overhydration.
Incorrect. The tissue may feel squishy but that is not the correct term.
Correct. This is the term for tissue which has accumulated excess fluid.
Correct. Although confusing the smallest conduit of lymph is also termed a capillary.
Incorrect. Arterioles are part of the blood distribution system leaving the heart.
Incorrect. Kidney tubules filter blood, not lymph.
Incorrect. This is the term for fluid in the tissues.
Incorrect. There is more to this liquid than water; it also contains proteins, electrolytes and other molecules.
Correct. The fluid inside a lymph vessel is referred to as lymph.
Incorrect. Lymph nodes are scattered along the paths of the lymph vessels but they are not the main recipient of fluid.
Correct. Like blood the tube that conducts lymph is called a vessel.
Incorrect. The spleen filters blood, not lymph.
Correct. The large lymph ducts run parallel to the blood vessels.
Incorrect. They nodes are more like islands in the river not the channel that holds the river.
Incorrect. Organs have many functions, not just lymph conduction.
Correct. Lymph does eventually get returned to the circulatory system.
Incorrect. The blood in the arteries is pumped into them by the heart.
Incorrect. The blood in the arteries is pumped into them by the heart.
Incorrect. The kidneys filter blood.
Incorrect. The blood capillaries carry blood.
Correct. Transit time is high in the lymph nodes which facilitates debris removal and activity by immune cells.
